head.title: From the Land of Port, a White

hedline.hl1: From the Land of Port, a White

abstract.p: Howard G Goldberg column recommends '98 Porca de Murca reserva blanco from Portugal's Real Vinicola winery

block.p: Predictably, the 21st century will elevate sleeper wine regions like Portugal, Puglia in southern Italy, and the Finger Lakes of New York, which have barely opened their jewelry cases.

The fruity '98 Porca de Murca reserva blanco (white), from a winery called Real Vinicola in the Douro, the northeastern Portugal region famous for Port, symbolizes the charm of the country's smartest modern whites.
Predictably, the 21st century will elevate sleeper wine regions like Portugal, Puglia in southern Italy, and the Finger Lakes of New York, which have barely opened their jewelry cases.

The fruity '98 Porca de Murca reserva blanco (white), from a winery called Real Vinicola in the Douro, the northeastern Portugal region famous for Port, symbolizes the charm of the country's smartest modern whites.
A spicy, floral bouquet gives way to a splendidly delicate, creamy, slightly spritzy, citric flavor that, in dryness and light weight, brings white Graves to mind.

Possibly the elegance can be traced to Jerry Luper, a longtime California winemaker (Chateau Montelena, Freemark Abbey, Diamond Creek, Rutherford Hill), who lives and works in Portugal and consults for Real Vinicola.

Except for semillon (boal in Portuguese), the other grapes in the blend, verdelho and cercial, are unfamiliar here -- a benefit, because Porca de Murca offers a new flavor experience that equals, say, piquant Spanish alberino in interest.
Pour the wine, lightly chilled, with mildly flavored fish, chicken and pork dishes.

The wine costs $9 at P. J.'s Wine Warehouse, 4898 Broadway (204th Street) and at 86th Street Wines, 306 East 86th (Second Avenue), Manhattan; $10 at Principe, 45-22 46th Street (Queens Boulevard), Sunnyside, Queens; $10 at Paley, 88 Seventh Avenue (Union Street), Park Slope, Brooklyn.
